title: Yankees pounce on Justin Verlander early, send ALCS back to Houston with Game 5 win
text:
But the New York Yankees, with elimination all the way up to their doorstep, play on. On Friday night, they held off the Houston Astros, 4-1, in Game 5 of the American League Championship Series at Yankee Stadium and staved off winter for another day.

As the Washington Nationals stand by, waiting to learn the identity of their World Series opponents, the ALCS moves back to Houston — where summer still hasn’t departed, with high temperatures in the upper 80s, and where Game 6 will be played Saturday night at Minute Maid Park. The Astros still lead the best-of-seven series, three games to two.

AD

AD

Both teams left their pitching plans for Game 6 as TBA, but both will approach it as a bullpen game, with Astros right-hander Jose Urquidy and Yankees lefty J.A. Happ likely to get the biggest chunks of the innings — perhaps following openers to the mound.

On Friday night, lefty James Paxton, acquired via trade 11 months ago precisely for moments such as this, delivered a season-saving performance for the Yankees, pitching six strong innings when almost anything less might have done them in, given the dwindling resources in their bullpen. Aaron Hicks’s three-run homer off Astros starter Justin Verlander in the first inning — a shot that curled and bent and finally clanged off the foul pole in right field — paced the offense.

The Yankees’ win didn’t alter the series’ fundamental equation. The Astros still get the next two games at Minute Maid Park, where they posted the best home record in the majors this season. They still have ace Gerrit Cole lined up as their firewall in a potential Game 7. And the Yankees will need more heroic pitching performances over the weekend.

AD

AD

But the Yankees’ victory at the very least halted the runaway momentum the Astros had gained over three straight wins and dented their sense of invulnerability.

“We’re up 3-2. We’re in the driver’s seat. We’re going back to Houston. But this is a great ballclub,” Verlander said of the Yankees. “I know there’s been some talk about them not playing so great the last couple days. But this team is stacked. They gave me great at-bats in Houston [in Game 1], and they continued to do so tonight. . . . They’re not going to lay down for us.”

After a wild first inning that portended an offensive free-for-all — with the Astros taking advantage of some sloppy play to hang an early run on Paxton and the Yankees smashing two homers off Verlander — both pitchers settled in, and the game was transformed almost instantly into a fast-moving, mesmerizing pitchers’ duel. Verlander, a leading candidate for the AL Cy Young Award, was particularly dominant after the first, retiring 20 of his final 21 batters, eight of them by strikeout.

AD

AD

It was the rare postseason game in which the most dramatic moment all night might have been a mound visit.

With two outs in the sixth, the Yankees holding a three-run lead and Paxton’s pitch count at a season-high 111, Yankees Manager Aaron Boone emerged from his dugout and strolled to the mound. The crowd of 48,483, anticipating Paxton’s removal — this being a spot where the Yankees hardly ever extend their starter — began to rise to its feet for a hearty ovation. But after Paxton convinced Boone to let him stay in, the latter returned to the dugout alone — to a massive roar.

“There wasn’t a lot said,” Paxton said of the pivotal mound visit. “He just said, ‘Do you have anything more left in the tank?’ And I said: ‘Yeah, let’s go. I want this.’ ”

AD

Moments later, left fielder Brett Gardner, his back against the wall, was settling under Robinson Chirinos’s deep drive to end the inning, and Paxton — perhaps spared by the grace of a de-juiced ball — pumped his arms wildly as he came off the mound.

AD

“I was begging it to stay in,” Paxton said of Chirinos’s drive, “and it did.”

This time, Paxton’s night was really over, but the Yankees still had nine outs to get. Facing the possibility of four games in four nights — the result of Wednesday night’s rainout — Boone wanted to stay away from right-handers Chad Green and Adam Ottavino, who had pitched Thursday. That left righty Tommy Kahnle, lefty Zack Britton and closer Aroldis Chapman, among Boone’s most trusted arms, to finish the job — which they did with scarcely a stumble.

AD

The Yankees didn’t lose a home series this year after mid-April, either winning or splitting 23 series in a row at Yankee Stadium. But they lost two of three to the Astros here this week, bottoming out in Thursday night’s Game 4, a loss in which they committed four errors and stranded 10 base runners. That put them in the unenviable position of having to face Verlander on Friday night with their season on the line.

AD

Since 2012, Verlander had made four starts against the Yankees in October, allowing a total of four earned runs over those starts. On Friday night, he gave up that many in the first inning. The Yankees ambushed him, with the big blow Hicks’s three-run homer — on a 3-2 slider after Verlander had gotten ahead 0-2. The homer snapped an 0-for-15 stretch by Yankees hitters with runners in scoring position, dating from Game 2.

The inning telegraphed the Yankees’ intention to be aggressive with Verlander: DJ LeMahieu slammed his second pitch of the game into the right field seats for a leadoff homer, Aaron Judge roped his fifth pitch to left for a single, and Gleyber Torres rifled his eighth pitch into the left field corner for a double.

AD

“I feel like the game was moving fast,” Chirinos, the Astros’ catcher, said of the first-inning ambush. “I should have called timeout and talked to him. That was my fault.”

AD

The Yankees are trying to become the third team this decade to fall behind three games to one in a best-of-seven playoff series and come back to win, joining the 2016 Chicago Cubs (over the Cleveland Indians in the World Series) and the 2012 San Francisco Giants (over the St. Louis Cardinals in the NLCS).

They needed three wins to pull it off, and now they need two. But those two must come in Houston, and there is no room for error. By the end of the weekend, even there, it will be winter for somebody.

description: Aaron Hicks’s three-run homer in the first inning and six solid innings from James Paxton gave New York a 4-1 victory.
